name: Castle
summary: Residence of the Archbishops of St Andrews
text: St Andrews Castle was home to the Catholic archbishops of St Andrews. A number of leading Protestants were imprisoned here before their trials inSt Andrews Cathedral. In March 1546 the Reformist preacher George Wishart was hanged and burned outside the castle, in the presence of Cardinal David Beaton. Slightly over two months later, in May 1546, a group of Fife lairds murdered Cardinal Beaton in revenge for Wishart’s execution. Beaton’s assassins took control of the castle, sparking a year-long siege. The remains of a mine and counter-mine from the siege can still be explored today.

The castle was recaptured by French forces in the summer of 1547, and Catholic control of St Andrews was temporarily re-established. During the 1550s Archbishop John Hamilton ordered major building work to repair damage from the siege. Hamilton created the present day entrance to the castle, which is decorated with his family symbol of the cinquefoil (a flower with five petals).

The castle returned to Protestant hands when Archbishop Hamilton fled from St Andrews in June 1559. In the ensuing conflict of the Scottish Reformation, St Andrews Castle became a major Protestant stronghold. It fell into ruins in the seventeenth century.

name: Cathedral
text: Before the Reformation St Andrews Cathedral was the largest religious building in Scotland. It housed the relics of St Andrew (the nation’s patron saint), and was the base for the archbishop of St Andrews (the most important churchman in the kingdom). During the early sixteenth century the Cathedral was the scene of major heresy trials. The last person to be tried for heresy in the Cathedral was the Protestant Walter Mylne, who was condemned to death in April 1558. At the time of his trial Mylne was over eighty years old.

A priory of Augustinian canons was attached to the Cathedral. The canons cared for the shrine of St Andrew and undertook the day to day running of the Cathedral church. St Andrews Cathedral Priory had a complicated relationship with religious reform. On the one hand, the priory was a Catholic religious institution which until 1559 publicly upheld Scotland’s traditional church hierarchy. Yet on the other hand, a number of key figures within the Cathedral Priory were personally sympathetic to religious reform. During the 1550s the sub-prior John Winram supported reformist policies within the Catholic church. Following the Reformation Winram played a major role in the establishment of Protestantism in Fife.  Similarly, the prior of St Andrews Cathedral, Lord James Stewart, became one of the most important leaders of the Protestant cause in Scotland during and after the Reformation of 1559.

In June 1559 Protestant Reformers (inspired by John Knox and supported by Lord James) determined to purge the Cathedral of all ‘monuments of idolatry’. The Reformers smashed statues and altars, and burnt images, vestments and mass books. At this time a number of the Cathedral canons ‘put off their habits’ and openly joined the Protestant cause. After the Reformation the focus of religious activity in St Andrews shifted to the parish church of Holy Trinity, and the Cathedral church was gradually dismantled and abandoned. However, the wider Cathedral site (which included the area now covered by St Leonard’s School) continued to be occupied, and had houses, mills, barns, and gardens into the nineteenth century.

name: Deans Court
summary: Home of the Archdeacons of St Andrews
text: Deans Court belonged to the archdeacon of St Andrews – one of the more important churchmen in the diocese of St Andrews. The archdeacon was regarded as the ‘archbishop’s eye’, and was responsible for inspecting parish churches and testing candidates for the priesthood.

In the sixteenth century Deans Court was often referred to as the ‘Archdean’s Inns’ (inn being the traditional term for a large urban residence). The well in the courtyard of the property can be seen on the oldest surviving map of St Andrews (the so-called Geddy Map from about 1580).

At the Reformation the Catholic archdeacon of St Andrews, George Durie, left the city, eventually going into exile in France. Deans Court initially passed to Durie’s relatives, the Pitcairns, but soon changed hands.
Just outside the gates of Deans Court there is a marker in the paving indicating where the Protestant Walter Mylne may have been burnt for heresy in the spring of 1558.

name: Holy Trinity
summary: The Parish Church of St Andrews
text: The parish church of Holy Trinity was where many of the ordinary residents of St Andrews worshipped. Before the Reformation it housed the altars of the local craft guilds, and about thirty Catholic priests were attached to the church. The priests spent much of their time saying masses for the dead in an effort to speed the souls of pious benefactors through Purgatory (according to Catholic theology the place where souls were ‘purged’ of sin before entering Heaven).

Although founded as a Catholic church, Holy Trinity was the scene of key events in St Andrews’ Reformation. In 1547, during the siege of St Andrews Castle, Holy Trinity became the focus of preaching by Catholics and Protestants, with each side putting forward their interpretation of Christianity. A young John Knox was among the Protestant preachers, and he delivered his first ever public sermon at Holy Trinity – an oration which led some listeners to conclude he would be burnt for heresy!

John Knox returned to Holy Trinity in June 1559, where he preached a fateful sermon persuading the citizens of St Andrews to reject Catholicism and ‘corruption’, and likening their work to Christ driving ‘the buyers and the sellers forth of the Temple of Jerusalem’. This sermon is traditionally seen as the trigger for St Andrews’ official adoption of Protestantism. Knox lived in St Andrews for several months during the Reformation crisis and was briefly minister of Holy Trinity Church.

Following the Reformation Holy Trinity became the focal point for Protestant worship in St Andrews. In 1559 Holy Trinity established one of the earliest kirk sessions in Scotland. The kirk session acted as a local church court and actively worked to enforce Protestant moral values. Offences as wide ranging as expressing Catholic sympathies, failing to attend church on Sunday, drunkenness, adultery, and domestic violence, were dealt with by the kirk session. In May 1564 the St Andrews Kirk Session proudly declared that ‘the face of a perfect reformed kirk has been seen within this city by the space of five years’. However, the sixteenth-century kirk session minutes tell a more complex story of defiance and disagreements.

name: Blackfriars
text: The Dominican order was founded in the early thirteenth century with the specific aims of preaching and fighting heresy. The Dominicans (also known as the black friars) came to St Andrews in the mid-fifteenth century. They expanded their presence in the city in the early sixteenth century, when they undertook major rebuilding work, including constructing an extension on the north side of their church (the remains of which can still be seen on South Street).

In general the Dominicans were committed Catholics, and a Dominican friar named Alexander Campbell played a key role in the trial and execution of Patrick Hamilton. However, on occasions the Dominicans’ preaching tradition could ignite controversy with the Catholic authorities. In 1536 the head of the Dominicans in St Andrews, Friar Alexander Seton, gave a series of controversial Lent sermons, which resulted in a major dispute with Archbishop James Beaton.

In the summer 1559 the black friars’ convent on South Street was one of the key locations attacked by the Reformers. According to a contemporary legal document the black friars were ‘violently expelled’ from their place. In April 1561 Friar John Grierson, the former head of the Dominican order in Scotland, complained that the St Andrews’ black friars’ church, cloister, and dormitories lay in ruins, and the friars were living in poverty.

name: Greyfriars
text: The Franciscan friary in St Andrews was founded in the mid-fifteenth century by Bishop James Kennedy. The Franciscans (or grey friars) were active preachers and took strict vows of personal and institutional poverty.

The St Andrews Franciscans seem to have had a good relationship with Cardinal David Beaton who made regular gifts of grain and money to the friary. The Franciscans actively assisted with the major heresy trials in sixteenth-century St Andrews – which perhaps contributed to their unpopularity at the Reformation.

On 18 May 1559 the St Andrews Franciscans handed over their property in St Andrews to the city officials. This grant may have been triggered by the sack of the friaries in Perth earlier in the month. Following St Andrews’ official adoption of Protestantism in June 1559 the grey friars left the city and went into exile on the Continent. The friary buildings were demolished, and the site is now covered by the street known as Greyfriars Garden.

name: St Leonard’s College
text: St Leonard’s College had close ties to St Andrews Cathedral. The college was founded in 1512 by the cathedral’s prior, John Hepburn, and by Alexander Stewart, then archbishop of St Andrews (and an illegitimate son of James IV). Until the Reformation the cathedral exerted considerable influence over St Leonard’s lands and administration, and many of the early academics at the college were also canons at the cathedral.

Before the establishment of a college, the St Leonard’s site had been a hospital providing accommodation for pilgrims visiting the cathedral. However, by the early sixteenth century pilgrimage to St Andrews had declined, and the hospital was occupied by a group of poor elderly women, who (according the college’s foundation charter) gave ‘little or no return in devotion or duty’. These women were cast out to make way for the new college where men would be educated ‘to the glory of God and the spiritual edification of the people’.

During the mid-sixteenth century St Leonard’s College acquired a reputation for being sympathetic to religious reform. John Knox records how following the execution of Patrick Hamilton many at the college began to question ‘the vanity of the received superstition’. According to one slightly later tradition early Scottish Protestants were sometimes said to ‘have drunk of St Leonard’s well’.

name: St Mary’s College
summary: University College Founded to Fight Heresy
text: At the time of the Reformation, St Mary’s College on South Street was often referred to as the ‘New College’. St Mary’s was the last of the three university college founded in St Andrews before the Reformation.

Plans for a college dedicated to the Virgin Mary were put together by Archbishop James Beaton shortly before his death in 1539. His nephew and successor Cardinal David Beaton commissioned new buildings for the college. French masons came to advise on the construction work, while marble for the altar in the college chapel was shipped by boat to St Andrews. Cardinal Beaton’s murder in May 1546 delayed the college’s completion. However, Archbishop John Hamilton supported further work, and in the 1550s St Mary’s opened its doors to students.

The college was intended by its founders to educate Catholic churchmen to resist heresy and schism. Yet, when St Andrews officially adopted Protestantism in the summer of 1559, most of the St Mary’s academics seem to have outwardly accepted the religious changes. In the later sixteenth century the college was reorganised to provide a Protestant religious education. It remains the Divinity department for the University of St Andrews.

name: St Mary’s on The Rock
summary: Catholic Church Closed at the Reformation
text: The Church of St Mary’s on the Rock, also known as St Mary’s Kirk Heuch, was sited on the cliffs overlooking the harbour, not far from the cathedral walls. It was a collegiate church – by which is meant a church run by a self-governing community of priests (in many ways rather like a cathedral chapter). During the late Middle Ages St Mary’s was a royal chapel, but it probably lost this status in the early 1500s.

St Mary’s on the Rock was reputedly sacked during the the Reformation of 1559. In April 1561 John Winram, by then the Protestant Superintendent of Fife, decreed that St Mary’s was ‘a profane house’. It was perhaps around this time that the church building was demolished, leaving the cross-shaped foundations which can be seen today.

While some of the priests attached to St Mary’s at the Reformation joined the Protestant Kirk, others resisted. One of the St Mary’s priests who rejected the religious changes was a man named Thomas Methven. In August 1561 Methven was summoned before John Winram to account for his refusal to join the Protestant Congregation. Methven retorted that ‘he was neither a Papist, nor a Calvinist, nor of Paul, nor of Apollo, but Jesus Christ’s man’.

name: St Salvator’s College
summary: University College and Site of Patrick Hamilton’s Execution
text: St Salvator’s College (literally the College of the Holy Saviour) was founded in the mid-fifteenth century by Bishop James Kennedy with the aims of furthering ‘divine wisdom’ and strengthening Catholicism against heresy and schism. Kennedy’s foundation was inspired by the university colleges at Oxford and Cambridge.

At the time of the Reformation St Salvator’s was the most established of the three university colleges in St Andrews. In 1528 the Reformer Patrick Hamilton was burnt as a heretic outside the gates of St Salvator’s. The approximate site of the execution is marked by a PH in the cobbles on the pavement.

When the St Andrews’ authorities subsequently embraced Protestantism several of the academics at St Salvator’s remained loyal to Catholicism and went into exile. The college’s provost William Cranston was among the masters who refused to convert. Cranston left St Andrews, reputedly taking with him ‘jewels and very costly silver work’.

name: Tolbooth
text: St Andrews’ Tolbooth (or town hall) was located in the middle of Market Street. The medieval building was demolished in the nineteenth century, but the outline of its foundations is marked in the modern paving on the road.

The Tolbooth was the heart of St Andrews’ local secular government. In the sixteenth century the St Andrews burgh council and burgh court met here. The burgh council played a key role in St Andrews’ decision to reject Catholicism, and seem to have actively endorsed attacks on the city’s religious houses in the summer of 1559.

Following the Reformation the burgh council initally co-operated with the Protestant church authorities, and there was considerable overlap between the burgh officials and the members of the Kirk Session at Holy Trinity Church. In the mid 1560s a new council chamber was built at the west end of the Tolbooth with money which had previously been allocated to the upkeep of Catholic chaplainries at Holy Trinity.

Later in the sixteenth century relations between the burgh council and the Protestant ministers of Holy Trinity deteriorated. In the 1580s it was alleged that the burgh council were preventing the minister receiving his stipend by conspiring with local gentlemen, and spending the money on ‘golf, archery, and good cheer’.
